ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES



Alta Dena Dairy, founded in 1945, produces and distributes quality dairy products for a wide range of customers from its City of Industry facility.  Construction of the facility was completed in 1998. Alta Dena Dairy's 250,000 sq. ft. plant has fully automated dairy processing and product handling systems.  As stated on their website, Alta Dena Dairy's vision is to "be the most admired and trusted provider of wholesome, great tasting dairy products at every occasion."  In 1999, Dean Foods Company acquired Alta Dena Dairy.



Alta Dena Dairy's senior management is not only committed to offer superior service, but also maintain a safety and environmental program to promote a safe environment for all its employees and the surrounding communities.  Alta Dena Dairy has an Emergency Action Plan

(Plan) in effect, which is detailed in the Emergency Planning and Response section of the PSM / CalARP / RMP document maintained at the facility.  The Plan provides the response organization and notification procedures, evacuation routes, ammonia health hazards, and mitigation procedures which will be implemented to respond effectively to emergency situations that may arise at the facility.  This Plan is reviewed and updated at least once per year.  This Plan will be reviewed and updated to ensure compliance with the PSM, CalARP, and RMP regulations, as well as to incorporate any facility changes.



STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE



The ammonia refrigeration system at Alta Dena Dairy facility was built in 1997 and began operations in 1999.  The facility is located at 17851 East Railroad Street, City of Industry, California, which is just north of Highway 60 and approximately 5 miles east of Highway 57.  The area immediately surrounding the facility is urban.  The system and the facility were constructed in accordance with 1994 Uniform Fire and Mechanical Codes. 



The refrigeration system uses ammonia for the following three main purposes: To provide cooling for 1) dairy processing, 2) warehouse cold storage, and 3) HVAC (Heating, Ventilation, and Air Conditioning) for offices.  With the exception of the condensers and the diffusion box (including associated piping), the entire ammonia system is located inside the engine room.



 

The refrigeration cycle begins with the transfer of ammonia from the thermosyphon receiver to the high pressure receiver.  The thermosyphon receiver also supplies ammonia to the compressors for oil cooling.  From the high pressure receiver, high pressure liquid ammonia is transferred to three accumulators (AC-1, AC-2 & AC-3) and 21F Accumulator (AC-5) that maintain ammonia at different temperatures.  As the ammonia enters each accumulator/surge drum, it is expanded through a hand expansion valve, reducing the temper

ature and the pressure.  Each accumulator/surge drum supplies liquid ammonia to a distinct heat exchanger which provides cooling for one of the three purposes listed above, vaporizing the ammonia.  The heat exchangers are located in the engine room and use a secondary fluid (glycol and/or water) to provide the required cooling throughout the facility.



The vapor is returned to each accumulator/surge drum in which constant pressures are maintained by back pressure regulating valves.  The vapor from two of the accumulators (AC-1 & AC-2) and 21F Accumulator (AC-5) is then pulled by the compressors (6) where the pressure and temperature of the gas is increased.  Suction from the other accumulator (AC-3) is drawn to the Suction Accumulator (AC-4).  Designated compressor(s) pull high side suction from AC-4, while any residual liquid is sent back to the High Pressure Receiver via the liquid transfer unit.  Upon reaching a level set point in the transfer unit, hot gas discharge from the compressors pressurizes the vessel and the liquid is then returned to the high pressure receiver.  Compressor discharge (high pressure ammonia vapor, or hot gas) is sent to the four condensers where it is condensed to a high pressure liquid and returned to the thermosyphon receiver.  An Auto Purger periodically purges the system of non-condensibles collected in the high pressure receiver and the condensers.  The system also has a diffusion box (for equalizing pressure between vessels in the system), and a dilution tank (into which the relief header vents), which is kept full of water.  



HAZARD ASSESSMENT SUMMARY



Result Summary



As part of this analysis, the EPA Toxic Endpoint (TE) for ammonia, 200 ppm, was used to quantify the off-site impact for the facility.  Table 2 summarizes the maximum downwind distances to the TE and the estimated residential populations that are at risk of being exposed to the TE concentration for each release.  The residential population at-risk nu

mber is the estimated number of people living within the radius of the maximum downwind distance reached by the plume in all wind directions.



This Risk Management Plan contains information from the most recent Hazard Assessment, which was completed in November of 2018.  The population was estimated using 2010 census tract data.  Release information was calculated using RMP*Comp.  



The RMP requires that facilities also consider "Environmental Receptors" defined as: areas such as national or state parks, forests, or monuments; wildlife sanctuaries, preserves, refuges, or areas; and Federal wilderness areas.  There were no environmental receptors located within the furthest downwind distance of 0.90 miles.



Worst Case Release Result Summary



The worst case release scenario is a release of the largest quantity of a regulated substance from a vessel or process line failure that results in the greatest distance to a specified endpoint.  The total ammonia charge consisted of 13,520 pounds of ammonia.  The largest vessel in the system, the High Pressure Receiver, can hold the entire ammonia charge, the entire ammonia charge of 13,520 pounds was assumed to be released. Note:  All vessels are located indoors; therefore, the release that results in the greatest distance to the endpoint is a mitigated release from the largest vessel.



Only the first 10 minutes of the release for solutions under ambient conditions is required for estimating the off-site consequences, because the toxic component in a solution evaporates fastest during the first few minutes of a spill, when its concentration is highest.  For the worst case scenario, a wind speed of 1.5 meters/second and stable conditions (F class stability) were used, based on EPA requirements.  

EPA's RMP*Comp was used to determine release rates and distances.  The worst case release reached 0.90 miles off site and may impact population receptors.  No environmental receptors were affected by this potential release.

The population receptors that may be affected by this worst case release scenario included schools residences and major commercial areas.  See Figure 2.



Alternative Release Result Summary



The alternative release scenario presented is similar to the worst case in that it is a liquid release.  The alternative release scenario chosen for this facility is that of a pipe leak.  It is assumed that this release is from the high side of the system.  The release scenario is assumed to last for 30 minutes, thereby incorporating active mitigation measures such as the emergency response procedures.  This would result in a loss of 3,540 lbs of ammonia.  Passive mitigation was not considered for the release, since the release could occur from ammonia equipment or piping located outside of building walls.



EPA allows a facility to use typical meteorological conditions at the facility. For this scenario, a wind speed of 3 meters/second and neutral conditions, D stability, were used to find the distance to the toxic endpoint of 200 ppm in an urban area.



EPA's RMP*Comp was used for this calculation.  This release reaches 0.09 miles off site and may impact population receptors (commercial businesses).  No environmental receptors were affected by this potential release.



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS



The Alta Dena Dairy facility was designed and constructed in accordance with the 1994 Uniform Mechanical Code which specifically outlines requirements for the safe operation of ammonia refrigeration systems.  These safety features include a water diffusion tank, ammonia sensors in the engine room, and automatic shut down systems.  In addition, all of the ammonia is located inside the engine room or on the engine room roof (condensers).  The facility uses a heat transfer medium to provide cooling throughout the plant.



Alta Dena Dairy's ammonia refrigeration system has many safety features.  Much of the safety associated with

the system is inherent in the policies and procedures that govern the operation of the system.  For example, the facility operates in accordance with Cal OSHA's Process Safety Management regulation.



DETECTION AND MONITORING: One ammonia sensor is located in a key location in the facility (engine room). The facility in-house maintenance personnel circulate throughout the plant, taking note of unusual conditions in any portion of the system.  If a leak is detected or observed by any Alta Dena Dairy employee (or contractor), it is immediately reported to their supervisor who then notifies the Maintenance Department in order to take action to mitigate the leak.

Other safety features of the ammonia refrigeration system include: an emergency shut down button located outside the engine room that kills power to the engine room equipment (one outside each engine room door). The system can also be shut down electronically by the computer system. There are also relief valves on all pressure vessels and condensers and continuous ventilation in the engine room to prevent ammonia explosions.



In addition to the Uniform Mechanical Code, the facility operates in accordance with the International Institute of Ammonia Refrigeration (IIAR) guidelines.  In particular, the IIAR Bulletin 110, "Startup, Inspection, and Maintenance of Ammonia Refrigeration Systems".



FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



EPA's RMP Program defines "accident" as the following:



"The release must be from a covered process and involve a regulated substance held above its threshold quantity in the process.



The release must have caused at least one of the following:



?    On-site deaths, injuries, or significant property damage (?68.42(a)); or

?    Known offsite deaths, injuries, property damage, environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place (?68.42(a))."



Based on the above definition and an investigation into the facility's accident history conducted during the Hazard Assessment Update, there h

ave been no releases of ammonia that meet this criteria in the past five years (January 2014 through January 2019). In addition, there have been no injuries resulting from an ammonia release, nor any releases or "near misses" that warranted an internal incident investigation.  



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



The Alta Dena Dairy facility has adopted emergency response procedures and policies.  The Emergency Action Plan (Plan) is detailed in the Emergency Planning and Response section of the PSM/RMP/CalARP document, which is maintained at the facility.  This Plan was designed to meet the following objectives:



1.  To save lives.

2.  To minimize and avoid injuries.

3.  To protect the environment.

4.  To minimize property damage.



The Plan provides the response organization and notification procedures, evacuation routes, ammonia health hazards, and mitigation procedures which will be implemented to respond effectively to emergency situations that may arise at the facility.  This Plan is reviewed and updated at least once per year.  This Plan will be reviewed and updated to ensure compliance with the PSM and RMP regulations, as well as to incorporate facility changes due to the renovation of the facility.  The Plan is distributed to new hires who are required to read and sign a certification page.  Facility personnel receive annual training regarding the emergency procedures.



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



A Revalidation following the initial Process Hazard Analysis was conducted in 2004, 2009, 2014 and in 2018, which generated mitigation measures (recommendations) to improve safety at the Alta Dena Dairy facility located at 17851 East Railroad Street in the City of Industry, California.  The Alta Dena Dairy safety committee is planning to complete several items, including the recommendations, over the next year, as a continual effort to provide a safe work environment for their employees.  These changes include the following items:



1. Continue to tr

ain all employees in Process Safety Management and the facility Safety Plan/Programs.



2. Continue to have employee involvement in Safety Plan Development.



3. Continue employee involvement through safety team participation.



4. Continue internal and external safety audits/inspections and implement changes as needed.
